name: Xen Project
description: Xen Project is a Linux Foundation Collaborative Project that develops the Xen Hypervisor and related virtualization technologies. The Xen Hypervisor is a leading virtualization platform that is powering some of the largest clouds in production today, such as Amazon Web Services, Rackspace Public Cloud, Alibaba Cloud (Aliyun) and many hosting services. It also fosters the creation of lightweight Unikernel systems with the Mirage OS incubator project, as well as many independent efforts which use our hypervisor as a base for their work.
contribution_justification:
https://xenproject.org/developers/governance.html
https://xenproject.org/help/contribution-guidelines.html
floss_license_justification: Mostly GPLv2 with some files being released under more permissive licenses to allow interaction with other open source projects. Some sub-projects use MIT or BSD style licenses. The GPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The GPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
repo_public_justification:
Repositories are at https://xenbits.xen.org/gitweb/
Some sub-projects such as XAPI and MirageOS use github exclusively: see https://xenproject.org/developers/teams.html for mor einformation
repo_track_justification: Uses git/github to track
repo_interim_justification: Interim versions are put on git, not just final versions.
repo_distributed_justification: Uses git.
version_unique_justification: The primary single user uses git commit records (and signed release tags) to identify releases.
release_notes_justification: Release notes for major and minor releases are available from download pages, e.g. https://xenproject.org/downloads/xen-archives/xen-46-series/xen-460.html and https://xenproject.org/downloads/xen-archives/xen-46-series/xen-461.html.
release_notes_vulns_justification: We do this explicitly for point releases (e.g. https://xenproject.org/downloads/xen-archives/xen-46-series/xen-461.html). However, we do not explicitly list fixed vulnerabilities for major releases which by default contain fixes for all known vulnerabilities as listed in https://xenbits.xen.org/xsa/ up to the release date, unless there has been an oversight (note that this has not happened yet), in which case this would be stated in release notes.
report_responses_justification: The vast majority of bug reports are acknowledged.
enhancement_responses_justification: It is up to contributors to submit enhancement requests: the Xen Project developers almost never accept "enhancement requests" on their own, unless these are very popular requests from https://xenorg.uservoice.com/forums/172169-xen-development. However the vast majority of enhancement requests by contributors, are merged within the required time period (see https://xen.biterg.io:443/goto/edb2f27b8c1cf85113ab55a58e218a13)
report_archive_justification: Reports and responses are handled as described in https://wiki.xenproject.org/wiki/Reporting_Bugs_against_Xen_Project https://wiki.xenproject.org/wiki/Reporting_Bugs_against_Xen_Project]. Many reports are initially handled via mailing lists, which are searchable via http://xen.markmail.org/ (subject:BUG). The bug tracker is also used (and is searchable); it is described at https://wiki.xenproject.org/wiki/Xen_Bug_Management_Interface
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: The project's security team typically responds within one working day.
test_justification: See https://xenbits.xen.org/gitweb/?p=osstest.git;a=summary, https://xenbits.xen.org/gitweb/?p=xtf.git;a=summary and the xentesttools repositories on https://xenbits.xen.org/gitweb
test_invocation_justification: See the README files in the relevant repositories, as well as https://xenbits.xen.org/docs/xtf/
test_most_justification: The OSSTEST suite and the Test Farm which executes OSSTEST tests all official git code branches. However, the test coverage of OSSTEST does not cover all input fields and functionality. Several vendors (e.g. Citrix, Oracle & SUSE) have their own extensive test suites (including test infrastructure), which are executed on release candidates. These suites have an extremely high degree of coverage. It would not be possible for the project to run these suites and operate the infrastructure due to the Hardware that would be required.
test_policy_justification: We do not currently do this for all new features: only for supported new features. For new features in preview or experimental state we do not require automated tests. In addition, testing of new drivers and hardware features can be challenging due to hardware availability. To help address this issue, we developed a new test framework called XTF creating microkernel-based tests, and a suite of tests built using the framework. XTF is currently being integrated into OSSTEST, the project's CI / continuous integration / automated push gate system. Experimental and preview features are excluded.
tests_are_added_justification: The project has a graded approach for features are supported ranging from preview, experimental, supported to deprecated. For features to be marked as supported, tests in the project's CI infrastructure are required or contributors are required to run 3rd party tests in their own 3rd party CI loops and demonstrate positive test results on a releases release candidate.
tests_documented_added_justification: We do not yet have a documented policy. A formal policy was discussed (but not yet agreed) that requires all supported features to be automatically tested by OSSTEST, XTF, a 3rd party test system or manually with test reports sent in for RCs. We have not yet fully formalised and documented this policy, as some areas such as 3rd party and manual test reports cannot currently be automatically submitted and checked without manual intervention. However, there are logistical challenges to enforcing and correctly documenting such a policy, which have not yet been fully resolved.
warnings_justification: We compile with -Wall -Wextra, and use Coverity
warnings_fixed_justification: We compile with -Werror, so warnings cannot be ignored.
warnings_strict_justification: We compile with -Wall -Wextra to turn on as many warnings as possible
know_secure_design_justification: The project has a dedicated security team that has a track record of designing secure software
know_common_errors_justification: The project has a dedicated security team that has a track record of fixing reported vulnerabilities
crypto_published_justification: We don't provide cryptographic libraries or facilities. The Xen hypervisor itself doesn't do any cryptography.
crypto_call_justification: We don't provide cryptographic libraries or facilities. The Xen hypervisor itself doesn't do any cryptography.
crypto_floss_justification: We don't provide cryptographic libraries or facilities. The Xen hypervisor itself doesn't do any cryptography.
crypto_keylength_justification: We don't provide cryptographic libraries or facilities. The Xen hypervisor itself doesn't do any cryptography.
crypto_working_justification: We don't provide cryptographic libraries or facilities. The Xen hypervisor itself doesn't do any cryptography.
crypto_pfs_justification: We don't provide cryptographic libraries or facilities. The Xen hypervisor itself doesn't do any cryptography.
crypto_password_storage_justification: We don't provide cryptographic libraries or facilities. The Xen hypervisor itself doesn't do any cryptography.
crypto_random_justification: We don't provide cryptographic libraries or facilities. The Xen hypervisor itself doesn't do any cryptography.
delivery_unsigned_justification: We provided PGP-signed tarballs and PGP-signed git tags, so that the recipient can verify that they are getting the right bits.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: These are reported to the security team, which handles the issues. See https://www.xenproject.org/security-policy.html
dynamic_analysis_justification:
The project runs American Fuzzy Lop over some portions of the codebase as part of its test infrastructure. This capability is being extended to cover more components. In addition tests which verify whether discovered, disclosed and fixed vulnerabilities are present in releases and master are run as part of the project's test infrastructure.

In addition, 3rd party test infrastructure which has extensive fuzzing capability (such as Citrix' XenRT) are run on RCs (but also at regular intervals between releases) as part of the projects release process and issues are reported to the Xen Security team.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Vendors such as Citrix, Oracle and SUSE, run their own test suites which for example in the case of Citrix who runs XenRT includes fuzzing functionality on XEN PROJECT release candidates. The project also runs AFL on portions of the code base as part of its test infrastructure.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: The Xen Project code base has a large number of run-time assertions in DEBUG builds. The test infrastructure tests against both RELEASE and DEBUG builds.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: These are handled in the same way as we handle vulnerabilities. See https://www.xenproject.org/security-policy.html
crypto_weaknesses_justification: We don't provide cryptographic libraries or facilities. The Xen hypervisor itself doesn't do any cryptography.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: OSSTEST and the projects Test Farm implements continuous integration. In addition we do random build testing for different compilers (various gcc and clang versions) via Travis
discussion_justification: https://www.xenproject.org/help/mailing-list.html
no_leaked_credentials_justification: Private credentials are stored securely or in private repositories
english_justification: Besides in-tree documentation as highlighted earlier, the project has an entire website and wiki dedicated to documentation. See https://wiki.xenproject.org/ and https://www.xenproject.org/
hardening_justification: This is rather vague and needs more information to identify what is acceptable and what is not.
crypto_used_network_justification: We do not use HTTP as an RPC transport. The toolstack software uses cryptography for migration, but it just uses whatever ssh you have as a transport (by default). We do support VNC, which has some encryption features. The encryption is entirely done by qemu using TLS.
crypto_tls12_justification: After checking with the Linux Foundation, we were advised that we do not need to verify such choices for upstreams we depend on. In our case, we use QEMU which uses TLS for VNC.
crypto_certificate_verification_justific: After checking with the Linux Foundation, we were advised that we do not need to verify such choices for upstreams we depend on. In our case, we use QEMU which uses TLS for VNC. However, this doesn't seem like it could work given TLS's security model: the VNC server is the user's and it would have to get a cert somehow.
crypto_verification_private_justificatio: We do not use HTTP as an RPC transport.
hardened_site_justification: X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
installation_common_justification: Many third parties provide packages (e.g., .deb for apt-get, .rpm). Since Xen is operating system like, installation is in general different than application software.
build_reproducible_justification: This would be a good idea. We don't have it right now, but we have accepted patches towards this goal (patches were submitted by the Debian reproducible builds folks).

name: libkaze
description:
Kaze is a scientific image processing library written in C.

The official Git repository can be found here:
[gitlab.com/tshack/kaze](https://gitlab.com/tshack/kaze)

Currently, Kaze provides:

  * A robust dynamic module system.  The Kaze library itself is a
    lightweight runtime system. Functionality is provided and extended
    by Kaze modules, which can be built directly into Kaze or loaded
    into the library at runtime.  Applications linking against Kaze can
    add support for additional file types and introduce new algorithms
    after release by shipping out modules to users.  Modules can be
    written in either C or C++.

  * A modular algorithm system called _Kaze Blocks_.  Kaze Blocks are
    built on top of Kaze's dynamic module system and can be distributed
    as files, which are loadable at runtime.  Kaze Blocks provide
    standardized interfaces for setting algorithm options and marshaling
    data.  With little effort, algorithm modules can be strung together
    to build powerful pipelines.

  * A reference based memory management system, which facilitates
    complicated workflows where object ownership may change or be
    managed across multiple threads of execution.

  * An N-dimensional image type providing mutable pixel buffers,
    in-place pixel type conversion, unlimited channels, and smart
    pixel iteration.

  * Beautifully detailed API documentation and author guides.

  * An ever increasing inventory of Kaze Blocks and file I/O modules!
description_good_justification: Kaze is a scientific image processing library written in C.
contribution_justification: https://gitlab.com/tshack/kaze/blob/develop/CONTRIBUTING.md
repo_public_justification: https://gitlab.com/tshack/kaze
repo_track_justification: https://gitlab.com/tshack/kaze/activity
repo_interim_justification: This project uses gitflow.  Development is performed in feature branches, which undergo code review prior to merging into the `develop` branch.  Stable releases are branched off of `develop` at stable points of development and merged into `master`.  The most recent `master` commit is always the more recent stable tagged release.  The `master` branch only contains tagged merge commits marking stable releases.  All release tags are signed with my PGP key.
repo_distributed_justification: Git is used.
version_tags_justification: Each release is marked with PGP signed Git tag
release_notes_justification:
The most recent __release__ version's changelog can be found here:
https://gitlab.com/tshack/kaze/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md

**OR** on the official website:

https://www.libkaze.org/md__builds_tshack_kaze_CHANGELOG.html

The most recent __development snapshot__ changelog can be found here:
https://gitlab.com/tshack/kaze/blob/develop/CHANGELOG.md
build_common_tools_justification: This project uses CMake (www.cmake.org) for build system generation.
test_most_justification:
The build system provides the `kaze_coverage` build target, which provides coverage reporting (lcov).  These reports are automatically generated and made available on the project website for commits/merges into `master` and can be perform locally by developers with minimal effort.  Coverage reporting for the latest release branch can be found on the project website at:

https://www.libkaze.org/coverage
warnings_justification: The default build mode for the project's `develop` branch includes `-Wall`
warnings_fixed_justification: The project aims to have no build warnings at all times.  Warnings should be fixed by developers in their respective feature branches before committing to the main development branch.  If false-positives, such warnings will be reevaluated before tagging a release merge into `master`
warnings_strict_justification: Project uses `-Wall` by default for all non-releases
static_analysis_justification:
Coverity is ran periodically during development phases and before releases.

https://scan.coverity.com/projects/libkaze
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Valgrind is ran periodically during development phases and before releases.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: The project uses GitLab's continuous integration system to automatically run the CTest based testing suite for all pushed commits.  Commits pushed to `master` additionally perform automatic coverage analysis.
discussion_justification: https://gitlab.com/tshack/kaze/issues
hardened_site_justification: X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".

name: GNU Wget
description:
GNU Wget is a free software package for retrieving files using HTTP, HTTPS and FTP, the most widely-used Internet protocols. It is a non-interactive command-line tool, so it may easily be called from scripts, cron jobs, terminals without X Window System support, etc.

GNU Wget has many features to make retrieving large files or mirroring entire web or FTP sites easy, including:

* Can resume aborted downloads, using REST and RANGE
* Can use filename wild cards and recursively mirror directories
* NLS-based message files for many different languages
* Optionally converts absolute links in downloaded documents to relative, so that downloaded documents may link to each other locally
* Runs on most UNIX-like operating systems as well as Microsoft Windows
* Supports HTTP proxies
* Supports HTTP cookies
* Supports persistent HTTP connections
* Unattended / background operation
* Uses local file timestamps to determine whether documents need to be re-downloaded when mirroring

name: cjdns
description: Cjdns implements an encrypted IPv6 network using public-key cryptography for address allocation and a distributed hash table for routing. This provides near-zero-configuration networking, and prevents many of the security and scalability issues that plague existing networks.
contribution_justification: https://github.com/cjdelisle/cjdns/blob/master/HACKING.md
repo_public_justification: github
repo_track_justification: github
repo_distributed_justification: git
version_semver_justification: the versions are called vX.Y (protocol change, patch change) instead of vX.Y.Z.
release_notes_vulns_justification: No public vulnerabilities found since early times before versions were established.
report_tracker_justification: Following the footsteps of Git project: http://apenwarr.ca/log/?m=200806#28
report_responses_justification: People talk about bugs on IRC, someone either investigates it, logs it or says it's not interesting to fix.
report_archive_justification: https://github.com/cjdelisle/cjdns/tree/master/doc/bugs bugs which have been triaged and validated go here.
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: We mean to treat all bugs the same way because there is no secret group of developers who have privileged knowledge about the software. The down-side is that the only way to disclose vulnerabilities is "full disclosure".
build_common_tools_justification: Custom build system using nodejs which provides greater flexibility.
test_invocation_justification: The build system is custom but the tests are automatically run at build time.
test_most_justification: This is highly up for interpretation but the major functionality is fairly well tested, especially aspects which are difficult to code.
tests_are_added_justification: Depends entirely on your definition of major but for now I'm going to claim it...
warnings_fixed_justification: -Werror implies that warnings are always fixed.
know_common_errors_justification: I'll claim that one as well...
crypto_published_justification: djb's nacl   curve25519, salsa20 and poly1305
crypto_call_justification:
We added a poly1305 implementation in mips32r3 assembly https://github.com/cjdelisle/cjdns/tree/master/node_build/dependencies/cnacl/crypto_onetimeauth/poly1305/mips32r2donna
which also exists here: https://github.com/cjdelisle/poly1305-mips32r2-donna this implementation is used only when the software is built on a MIPS platform and makes the encryption faster.

Also random.c https://github.com/cjdelisle/cjdns/blob/master/crypto/random/Random.c
crypto_random_justification: https://github.com/cjdelisle/cjdns/blob/master/crypto/random/Random.c   the good news is it's a secure random generator, the bad news is it's implemented in-house.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: no known vulnerabilities at this time.
static_analysis_justification:
jshint is used on the javascript aspects of the codebase.
Static analysis of the C code is complex as it is partially generated by the build tool.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: *technically* met because insecure javascript is scanned for and the build system is javascript.
static_analysis_often_justification: for jshint linting and C w/ warnings this is checked at each build (so checked by the CI server) https://github.com/cjdelisle/cjdns/blob/master/.travis.yml
dynamic_analysis_justification: There are tests which do fuzzing but these are custom tests, not using an external tool such as AFL.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Tests do fuzzing but this is custom..
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi:
yes yes yes https://github.com/cjdelisle/cjdns/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=Assert_true
Assert_true() -> enabled all of the time (even runtime)
Assert_ifParanoid() -> only enable if -DPARANOIA=1 (default true)
Disabling PARANOIA might save a little bit of performance.
discussion_justification: IRC is the primary method of conversation which does not have search. However, there is a bug tracker which is managed by friends who administer a fork. Reporting/discussing issues there is one way to communicate them to the "developers" (anyone who is interested in writing code for the project), but I don't check that tracker and I don't warrant it as "official" (another repository could take it's place or it could evaporate one day if people don't keep reporting and answering there).  Any really important (security) issues should make it back to me via various channels (people mentioning it to me on IRC) and I'll take the time myself to see that they're fixed, but this type of issue has never happened within my memory. One could imagine this all as a large and convoluted process for triaging bugs, and in some way it is reflective of the cjdns culture, everyone plays a role in one way or another.
hardening_justification:
-fstack-protector-all https://github.com/cjdelisle/cjdns/blob/master/node_build/make.js#L206
relro, noexecstack https://github.com/cjdelisle/cjdns/blob/master/node_build/make.js#L109
SECCOMP https://github.com/cjdelisle/cjdns/blob/master/util/Seccomp.c#L207
open-file limit 0 (optional, default disabled)  https://github.com/cjdelisle/cjdns/blob/master/util/Security.c#L103
RLIMIT_NPROC 0 https://github.com/cjdelisle/cjdns/blob/master/util/Security.c#L103
chroot(/var/run) https://github.com/cjdelisle/cjdns/blob/master/util/Security.c#L127
setuid(nobody) https://github.com/cjdelisle/cjdns/blob/master/util/Security.c#L60
crypto_used_network_justification: at runtime the software sends no data unless it is encrypted.
crypto_tls12_justification: at download time, github supports TLS1.2
crypto_certificate_verification_justific: no TLS used at runtime except possibly to download nodejs at build time but nodejs sha256 is checked here: https://github.com/cjdelisle/cjdns/blob/master/do#L80
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.
installation_common_justification: The software is to be downloaded with git and built on the target machine because the target audience are people who have capability to compile software. This requirement will be relaxed as the software matures.
build_reproducible_justification:
There exist a number of random numbers generated at build time so in order to have a reproducible build we need to change the random generator. Example of using a random number (for a heap canary): https://github.com/cjdelisle/cjdns/blob/master/memory/Allocator.c#L790
Generator of the random number using the custom build system: https://github.com/cjdelisle/cjdns/blob/master/util/Constant.h#L24
Where the random number gets generated: https://github.com/cjdelisle/cjdns/blob/master/util/Constant.js#L65

name: REST API automated testing tool based on RAML
description: Abao is a command-line tool for testing API documentation written in RAML format against its back-end implementation.
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
floss_license_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: We use [GitHub PRs] (https://github.com/cybertk/abao/pulls) of feature-specific Git branches to enable collaborative reviews.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: The [package.json] (https://github.com/cybertk/abao/blob/master/package.json) file is used to specify each new version.
version_tags_justification: We use generic SemVer with release versions following "<major>.<minor>.<bugfix>" format.
report_responses_justification: Email notification of new issues are normally responded to fairly quickly; often needed to get enough details about what was trying to be achieved. GitHub [issue tracker] (https://github.com/cybertk/abao/issues)
enhancement_responses_justification: Email notification of new features are normally responded to fairly quickly; often needed to get enough details about what was trying to be achieved. GitHub [issue tracker] (https://github.com/cybertk/abao/issues)
build_justification: Uses NPM to build the package via project's [package.json] (https://github.com/cybertk/abao/blob/master/package.json).
build_common_tools_justification: Uses NPM to build the package; other package dependencies may require a C compiler (e.g., gcc) be installed as well.
test_justification: Automated tests are part of project package itself. These are handled by Grunt invocation.
test_most_justification: Additional Mocha tests are typically added for each new bugfix/feature, located [here](https://github.com/cybertk/abao/tree/master/test) within package.
test_policy_justification:
PRs will generally require test(s) to be considered for merge.
They are added to [test suite]((https://github.com/cybertk/abao/tree/master/test)) upon merge.
tests_are_added_justification: See ``git log`` for individual test files [[example](https://github.com/cybertk/abao/blob/master/test/unit/test-runner-test.coffee)]
warnings_fixed_justification: Warnings are generally frowned upon, and fixed ASAP.
warnings_strict_justification: Our CoffeeLint settings are reasonably strict.
delivery_mitm_justification: [Project release downloads] (https://github.com/cybertk/abao/releases) available via HTTPS on GitHub.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Package itself is CoffeeScript, which translates to JavaScript -- no native code to check.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio:
Uses the Travis CI service to run test suite upon each commit.
Build history available [here] (https://travis-ci.org/cybertk/abao/builds).
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: No credentials available via GitHub project repository.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.

name: AuthZForce Core PDP engine (Community Edition)
description: Authorization PDP (Policy Decision Point) engine implementing the OASIS XACML v3.0.
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/authzforce/core/blob/develop/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
contribution_requirements_justification:
Requirements including the reference to coding standards are given on the CONTRIBUTING.md page:
https://github.com/authzforce/core/blob/develop/CONTRIBUTING.md#coding-rules
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/authzforce/core/blob/develop/LICENSE.txt>.
floss_license_justification: The GPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The GPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_interface_justification: See Javadoc artificat for each release on Maven: authzforce-ce-core-X.X.X-javadoc.jar
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: All the git commits and therefore all the versioning is managed on the public Github repository, including the develop branch where the main development is done before releasing to the master branch.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_tags_justification:
All releases available here: https://github.com/authzforce/core/releases
All tags available here: https://github.com/authzforce/core/tags
release_notes_justification: Non-trivial release notes file in repository: <https://github.com/authzforce/core/blob/develop/CHANGELOG.md>.
vulnerability_report_process_justificati:
This is explained in the Vulnerability Reporting section of the README:
https://github.com/authzforce/core#vulnerability-reporting
vulnerability_report_private_justificati:
This is explained in the Vulnerability Reporting section of the README:
https://github.com/authzforce/core#vulnerability-reporting
warnings_fixed_justification: Although in test classes, we allow more minor warnings such as missing Javadoc comment, we respect the rule in non-test classes.
warnings_strict_justification: We use owasp-dependency-check, PMD and findbugs that are configured to make the build fail in case of any warning.
delivery_mitm_justification: Releases are delivered as maven artifacts signed with PGP on Maven Central.
delivery_unsigned_justification: Released maven artifacts are signed with PDP, therefore use a cryptographic signature.
static_analysis_justification: At least PMD (maven plugin) is applied.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: The build fails if they are not fixed so a release cannot be done without it.
static_analysis_often_justification: Every commit assumes the code builds (mvn package) successfully.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: We used Java assertions and enable them (-ea) for all tests.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Maven builds are continuously run in Jenkins jobs.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
english_justification: Documentation in English (Github pages and Javadocs), bug reports or comments in English on Github issues
hardening_justification: Maven plugins for source code analysis from quality/security standpoint are applied: PMD, OWASP dependency-check, findbugs (+ findsecbugs).
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.
build_reproducible_justification: The source is a Maven project.
